items.label: Best Practices for Ethereum developers on NEAR
Set up Rust and a contract skeleton
Add basic code, create a subaccount, and call methods
Hash the solution, unit tests, and an init method

api/rpc/access-keys.title: Access Keys
api/rpc/access-keys.description: The RPC API enables you to retrieve information about an account's access keys.

api/rpc/block-chunk.title: Block / Chunk
api/rpc/block-chunk.description: The RPC API enables you to query the network and get details about specific blocks or chunks.

api/rpc/contracts.title: Accounts / Contracts
api/rpc/contracts.description: The RPC API enables you to view details about accounts and contracts as well as perform contract calls.

api/rpc/gas.title: Gas
api/rpc/gas.description: The RPC API enables you to query the gas price for a specific block or hash.

api/rpc/introduction.title: NEAR RPC API
api/rpc/introduction.description: The RPC API allows you to communicate directly with the NEAR network. For example,

api/rpc/maintenance-windows.title: Maintenance Windows
api/rpc/maintenance-windows.description: The RPC API enables you to query future maintenance windows for a specific validator in current epoch

api/rpc/network.title: Network
api/rpc/network.description: The RPC API enables you to query status information for nodes and validators.

api/rpc/protocol.title: Protocol
api/rpc/protocol.description: The RPC API enables you to retrieve the current genesis and protocol configuration.

api/rpc/providers.title: RPC Providers
api/rpc/providers.description: There are multiple RPC providers from which you can choose from. These providers will work as intermediaries to help you interact with the NEAR network.

api/rpc/setup.title: Setup
api/rpc/setup.description: In order to use the RPC API you will need to setup the correct RPC endpoints.

api/rpc/transactions.title: RPC Endpoints
api/rpc/transactions.description: The RPC API enables you to send transactions and query their status.

build/chain-abstraction/chain-signatures.title: Chain Signatures
build/chain-abstraction/chain-signatures.description: Chain signatures enable NEAR accounts, including smart contracts, to sign and execute transactions across many blockchain protocols.

build/chain-abstraction/data-availabilit.title: Rollup Data Availability
build/chain-abstraction/data-availabilit.description: Every monolithic blockchain has a data availability layer. NEAR's Data Availability (DA) represents a pioneering initiative to modularize the data availability layer from the NEAR blockchain to make it available as a roll-up solution for builders on other chains.

build/chain-abstraction/fastauth-sdk.title: FastAuth SDK
build/chain-abstraction/fastauth-sdk.description: FastAuth is a key management system that allows users to recover or sign-up for a NEAR account using their email address. Furthermore, it allows to subsidize gas for a certain smart contract, so users can interact with it without having to fund their account.

build/chain-abstraction/meta-transaction.title: Building a Meta Transaction Relayer
build/chain-abstraction/meta-transaction.description: Relayers serve to delegate gas fees to a web service, allowing users to transact on NEAR without the need to acquire the token themselves while still retaining the security of signing their own transactions. This guide will lead you through the components necessary to construct a relayer capable of handling meta transactions.

build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.title: Multichain Gas Station Contract
build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.description: The multichain gas station smart contract accepts payments in NEAR tokens in exchange for gas funding on non-NEAR foreign chains. Part of the NEAR Multichain effort, it works in conjunction with the MPC recovery service to generate on-chain signatures.

build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.title: Multichain Relayer Server
build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.description: The Multichain Relayer Server facilitates cross-chain transactions and enables Chain Abstraction.

build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.title: Multichain Gas Relayer Overview
build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.description: The Multichain Gas Relayer on NEAR is designed to facilitate cross-chain transactions by managing gas fees and transaction relays across different blockchain networks.

build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.title: Multichain Relayer and Gas Station example
build/chain-abstraction/multichain-gas-r.description: In this article you'll learn how to run end-to-end tests on the entire Multichain Relayer system.

build/chain-abstraction/nft-chain-keys.title: NFT Chain Keys Smart Contract
build/chain-abstraction/nft-chain-keys.description: The NFT Chain Keys smart contract makes the ownership of remote accounts both provable and transferrable. This new paradigm allows you to create new end-user experiences that leverage provable and transferrable remote accounts as a core primitive.

build/chain-abstraction/what-is.title: What is Chain Abstraction?
build/chain-abstraction/what-is.description: The idea behind chain abstraction is quite simple: blockchain technology should be abstracted away from the user experience. In other words, people should not realize when they are using a blockchain, nor which blockchain they are using.

build/data-infrastructure/big-query.title: BigQuery Public Dataset
build/data-infrastructure/big-query.description: Blockchain data indexing in NEAR Public Lakehouse is for anyone wanting to understand blockchain data. This includes:

build/data-infrastructure/lake-data-stru.title: Structures. Table of Contents
build/data-infrastructure/lake-data-stru.description: The structures described in this section of the docs are indexer-related more than nearcore related. Some of the are artificial and are not a part of nearcore

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: JS basic tutorial
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: near-examples/near-lake-raw-printer-js: source code for the tutorial on how to create an indexer that prints block height and number of shards

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: Building an NFT indexer
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: near-examples/near-lake-nft-indexer: source code for this tutorial

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: NEAR Lake Primitive Types
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: This article contains the primitive types used by the NEAR Lake Framework package. These types are used to define the data structures used by the framework as well as provide some popular helper functions.

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: NEAR Lake indexer basic tutorial
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: frolvanya/near-lake-raw-printer: source code for the tutorial on how to create an indexer that prints block height and number of shards

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: Building an NFT indexer for Python
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: frolvanya/near-lake-nft-indexer: source code for this tutorial

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: Migrating to NEAR Lake Framework
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: We encourage everyone who don't have a hard requirement to use NEAR Indexer Framework consider the migration to NEAR Lake Framework.

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: NEAR Lake Indexer
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: NEAR Lake is an indexer built on top of NEAR Indexer Framework to watch the network and store all the event logs such as FT Events and NFT Events as JSON files on AWS S3.

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: NEAR Lake Indexer Tutorial
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: near-examples/near-lake-accounts-watcher: source code for a video tutorial on how to use the NEAR Lake Framework

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: Credentials
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: To access the data provided by NEAR Lake you need to provide valid AWS credentials in order to be charged by the AWS for the S3 usage.

build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.title: Extending Lake indexer with start options
Running NEAR Lake Indexer
build/data-infrastructure/lake-framework.description: NEAR Lake is a blockchain indexer built on top of NEAR Indexer microframework

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/best.title: Indexing best practices
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/best.description: In this article you can find suggested best practices when building blockchain indexers using QueryAPI.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/how-.title: How QueryAPI works
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/how-.description: QueryApi is a streaming indexer implementation that executes custom indexing logic written by developers on the NEAR blockchain.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/inde.title: Indexing Functions
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/inde.description: QueryAPI is a fully managed service that allows you to create and manage indexers on-chain seamlessly.

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/inde.title: QueryAPI Indexing Example
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/inde.description: With QueryAPI you can quickly create your own indexer by:

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/intr.title: QueryAPI Overview
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/intr.description: Near QueryAPI is a fully managed solution to build indexer functions,

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/migr.title: Migrate from NEAR Lake framework
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/migr.description: In this article you'll learn how to migrate your NEAR Lake Framework JavaScript indexer to Near QueryAPI, a fully managed solution to build indexer functions,

build/data-infrastructure/query-api/quer.title: Accessing and Querying Historical data
build/data-infrastructure/query-api/quer.description: In this article, you'll find a high-level overview about the two most common use-cases for blockchain indexing, and how they can be solved using NEAR QueryAPI and BigQuery.

build/data-infrastructure/what-is.title: What is Data Infrastructure?
build/data-infrastructure/what-is.description: NEAR offers ready-to-use solutions to access and monitor on-chain data easily. This is very useful to automate actions based on specific events, cache data to reduce latency, gather usage data of the blockchain, and even study user preferences.

build/near-components/anatomy/bos-compon.title: Historical data
build/near-components/anatomy/bos-compon.description: Building components that handle historical blockchain data require dedicated solutions that manage the data and reduce the latency of requests, as it's not possible to scan the whole blockchain when a user makes a request.

build/near-components/anatomy/builtin-co.title: List of Native Components
build/near-components/anatomy/builtin-co.description: A list of all the built-in components to be used on Near Components.

build/near-components/anatomy/near.title: Interacting with Near
build/near-components/anatomy/near.description: The components can use the Near object to interact with smart contracts in the NEAR blockchain. There are three methods:

build/near-components/anatomy/notificati.title: Social Notifications
build/near-components/anatomy/notificati.description: Applications such as NEAR Social and the NEAR Dev Portal allow components to send notifications to their users.

build/near-components/anatomy/social.title: Social Interactions
build/near-components/anatomy/social.description: NEAR components can natively communicate with the SocialDB smart contract (currently deployed at social.near).

build/near-components/anatomy/state.title: Basics
build/near-components/anatomy/state.description: Borrowing from React, Near Components use hooks such as useState and useEffect to handle the state's logic, and props to receive parameters.

build/near-components/anatomy/web-method.title: Web Browser Methods
build/near-components/anatomy/web-method.description: NEAR Components have access to classic web methods that enable them to:

build/near-components/bos-gateway.title: Using components on WebApps
build/near-components/bos-gateway.description: In order to use the components you create in a WebApp you need to use what is known as the NEAR VM. This virtual machine helps you to easily fetch components from the blockchain and transform them into executable code.

build/near-components/dev-environment.title: Choose your Dev Environment
build/near-components/dev-environment.description: The environments in which you can develop Components are divided into two categories:

build/near-components/what-is.title: What are NEAR Components?
build/near-components/what-is.description: NEAR Components are a new way to build web applications. They are composable, reusable and decentralized.

build/primitives/dao.title: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations
build/primitives/dao.description: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) are self-organized groups that form around common purposes. Membership, decision making, and funding are coordinated by publicly voting on proposals through a smart contract.

build/primitives/dao/bos/create-dao.title: create-dao
build/primitives/dao/bos/create-dao.description: The full list of roles and permissions you can find here.

build/primitives/dao/bos/vote-for-propos.title: vote-for-proposal
build/primitives/dao/bos/vote-for-propos.description: Available vote options: VoteApprove, VoteReject, VoteRemove.

build/primitives/dao/near-cli/create-dao.description: The full list of roles and permissions you can find here.

build/primitives/dao/near-cli/vote-for-p.title: vote-for-proposal
build/primitives/dao/near-cli/vote-for-p.description: Available vote options: VoteApprove, VoteReject, VoteRemove.

build/primitives/dao/web-app/create-dao.description: The full list of roles and permissions you can find here.

build/primitives/dao/web-app/create-prop.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/dao/web-app/vote-for-pr.title: vote-for-proposal
build/primitives/dao/web-app/vote-for-pr.description: Available vote options: VoteApprove, VoteReject, VoteRemove.

build/primitives/dex.title: Decentralized Exchanges (DEX)
build/primitives/dex.description: A Decentralized Exchange (DEX) is an application that allows users to trade tokens (native & fungible tokens) through smart contracts.

build/primitives/dex/web-app/get-deposit.title: get-deposit-balances
build/primitives/dex/web-app/get-deposit.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/dex/web-app/swap.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/ft.title: Fungible Tokens (FT)
build/primitives/ft.description: Besides the native NEAR token, NEAR accounts have access to a multitude of tokens to use thoughtout the ecosystem. Moreover, it is even possible for users to create their own fungible tokens.

build/primitives/ft/bos/check-balance.title: check-balance
build/primitives/ft/bos/check-balance.description: Remember about fungible token precision. You may need this value to show a response of balance requests in an understandable-to-user way in your app. How to get precision value (decimals) you may find above.

build/primitives/ft/smart-contract/send.title: send
build/primitives/ft/smart-contract/send.description: This snippet assumes that the contract is already holding some FTs and that you want to send them to another account.

build/primitives/ft/web-app/check-balanc.title: check-balance
build/primitives/ft/web-app/check-balanc.description: Remember about fungible token precision. You may need this value to show a response of balance requests in an understandable-to-user way in your app. How to get precision value (decimals) you may find above.

build/primitives/ft/web-app/create.title: create
build/primitives/ft/web-app/create.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/ft/web-app/register.title: register
build/primitives/ft/web-app/register.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/ft/web-app/send.title: send
build/primitives/ft/web-app/send.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/linkdrop.title: Linkdrops
build/primitives/linkdrop.description: Linkdrops allow users to distribute assets and onboard people to Web3 apps through a simple web link.

build/primitives/nft.title: Non-Fungible Tokens (NFT)
build/primitives/nft.description: In contrast with fungible tokens, non-fungible tokens (NFT) are unitary and therefore unique. This makes NFTs ideal to represent ownership of assets such as a piece of digital content, or a ticket for an event.

build/primitives/nft/bos/list-for-sale.title: list-for-sale
build/primitives/nft/bos/list-for-sale.description: The method nftapprove will call nfton_approve in marketplace.paras.near.

build/primitives/nft/bos/mint.title: mint
build/primitives/nft/bos/mint.description: In order to use nft_mint method of the x.paras.near contract you have to be a creator of a particular token series.

build/primitives/nft/near-cli/list-for-s.title: list-for-sale
build/primitives/nft/near-cli/list-for-s.description: Method nftapprove of a NFT contract also calls the nfton_approve method in marketplace.paras.near as a callback.

build/primitives/nft/near-cli/mint.title: mint
build/primitives/nft/near-cli/mint.description: In order to use nft_mint method of the x.paras.near contract you have to be a creator of a particular token series.

build/primitives/nft/smart-contract/buy.title: buy
build/primitives/nft/smart-contract/buy.description: This is an example on how you can make your smart contract buy a NFT on some marketplace (Paras this case).

build/primitives/nft/smart-contract/tran.title: transfer
build/primitives/nft/smart-contract/tran.description: Please notice that a contract can only transfer an NFT that they own, or an NFT that they were approved to transfer.

build/primitives/nft/web-app/buy.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/nft/web-app/mint.description: In order to use nft_mint method of the x.paras.near contract you have to be a creator of a particular token series.

build/primitives/nft/web-app/query.title: query
build/primitives/nft/web-app/query.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/nft/web-app/transfer.title: transfer
build/primitives/nft/web-app/transfer.description: The Wallet object comes from our quickstart template

build/primitives/oracles.title: Price Oracles
build/primitives/oracles.description: Oracles are smart contracts that enable you to query the current price of an asset.

build/primitives/what-is.title: What are Primitives?
build/primitives/what-is.description: Primitives are fundamental building blocks that can be combined to create a fully functional application. Blockchain primitives include Fungible Tokens (FT), Non Fungible Tokens (NFT), Decentralized Autonomous organizations (DAO), Link Drops and more.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/actions.title: Transfers & Actions
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/actions.description: Smart contracts can perform specific Actions such as transferring NEAR, or calling other contracts.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/anatomy.title: Basic Anatomy
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/anatomy.description: Let's illustrate the basic anatomy of a simple "Hello World" contract. The code on this page comes from our Hello NEAR repository on GitHub.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/collection.title: Collections
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/collection.description: When deciding on data structures to use for the data of the application, it is important to understand the tradeoffs of data structures in your smart contract.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/crosscontr.title: Cross-Contract Calls
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/crosscontr.description: Your contract can interact with other deployed contracts, querying information and executing functions on them.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/environmen.title: Environment
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/environmen.description: Every method execution has an environment associated with information such as:

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/functions.title: External Interface
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/functions.description: Smart contracts expose functions so users can interact with them. There are different types of functions including read-only, private and payable.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/reproducib.title: Reproducible Builds
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/reproducib.description: Reproducible builds let different people build the same program and get the exact same outputs as one another. It helps users trust that deployed contracts are built correctly and correspond to the source code. To verify your contract user can build it themselves and check that the binaries are identical.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/serializat.title: Notes on Serialization
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/serializat.description: Smart contracts need to be able to communicate complex data in a simple way, while

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/serializat.title: Serialization Protocols
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/serializat.description: Serialization formats within the SDK define how data structures are translated into bytes which are needed for passing data into methods of the smart contract or storing data in state. For the case of method parameters, JSON (default) and Borsh are supported with the SDK and for storing data on-chain Borsh is used.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/storage.title: State
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/storage.description: Smart contracts store data in their account's state, which is public on the chain. The storage starts empty until a contract is deployed and the state is initialized.

build/smart-contracts/anatomy/types.title: SDK Types
build/smart-contracts/anatomy/types.description: Lets discuss which types smart contracts use to input and output data, as well as how such data is stored and handled in the contract's code.

build/smart-contracts/quickstart.title: Hello Contract
build/smart-contracts/quickstart.description: Welcome! NEAR accounts can store small apps known as smart contracts. In this quick tutorial, we will guide you in creating your first contract in the NEAR testnet!

build/smart-contracts/release/deploy.title: NEAR CLI - Basics
build/smart-contracts/release/deploy.description: After your contract is ready you can deploy it in the NEAR network for everyone to use it.

build/smart-contracts/release/lock.title: Locking Accounts
build/smart-contracts/release/lock.description: Removing all full access keys from an account will effectively lock it.

build/smart-contracts/release/upgrade.title: Updating Contracts
build/smart-contracts/release/upgrade.description: NEAR accounts separate their logic (contract's code) from their state (storage), allowing the code to be changed.

build/smart-contracts/security/bounty.title: Bug Bounty Program
build/smart-contracts/security/bounty.description: NEAR has a revamped bug bounty program!

build/smart-contracts/security/callbacks.title: Cross-Contract Calls
build/smart-contracts/security/callbacks.description: While writing cross-contract calls there is a significant aspect to keep in mind

build/smart-contracts/security/checklist.title: ‚úÖ Checklist
build/smart-contracts/security/checklist.description: Once you finished developing your smart contract please go through the following list in order to ensure everything is safe for the end user.

build/smart-contracts/security/frontrunn.title: Front Running
build/smart-contracts/security/frontrunn.description: In the NEAR network, validators have access to the transaction pool, and can therefore see them before they execute. This enables validators to analyze transactions for a potential profit and frontrun them with a transaction of their own.

build/smart-contracts/security/one-yocto.title: Ensure it is the User (1y‚ìÉ)
build/smart-contracts/security/one-yocto.description: NEAR uses a system of Access Keys to simplify handling accounts.

build/smart-contracts/security/random.title: Random Numbers
build/smart-contracts/security/random.description: When writing smart contracts in NEAR you have access to a random seed that enables you to create random numbers/strings

build/smart-contracts/security/reentranc.title: Reentrancy Attacks
build/smart-contracts/security/reentranc.description: Between a cross-contract call and its callback any method of your contract can be executed. Not taking this into account is one of the main sources of exploits. It is so common that it has its own name: reentrancy attacks.

build/smart-contracts/security/storage.title: Million Small Deposits
build/smart-contracts/security/storage.description: On NEAR, your contract pays for the storage it uses. This means that the more data you store, the more balance you need to cover for storage. If you don't handle these costs correctly (e.g. asking the user to cover their storage usage), then a million little deposits can drain your contract of its funds.

build/smart-contracts/security/sybil.title: Sybil Attacks
build/smart-contracts/security/sybil.description: While developing your smart contract, keep in mind that an individual can potentially create multiple NEAR accounts. This is especially relevant in ecosystems involving crowd decisions, such as DAOs.

build/smart-contracts/security/welcome.title: Security
build/smart-contracts/security/welcome.description: Here you will find information on how to keep your smart contract and decentralized applications secure.

build/smart-contracts/testing/integratio.title: Integration Tests
build/smart-contracts/testing/integratio.description: Integration tests enable to deploy your contract in the NEAR testnet or a local sandbox, and create test-users to interact with it. In this way, you can thoroughly test your contract in a realistic environment.

build/smart-contracts/testing/introducti.title: Introduction
build/smart-contracts/testing/introducti.description: While developing your smart contract you will want to test that it works as it is supposed to, and moreover, does so securely. In NEAR we have developed tools to help you carry out such tests. Basically, there are two types of tests you can perform:

build/smart-contracts/testing/kurtosis-l.title: Creating a Local Development Environment
build/smart-contracts/testing/kurtosis-l.description: Using Kurtosis NEAR Package to develop locally

build/smart-contracts/testing/unit-test.title: Unit Testing
build/smart-contracts/testing/unit-test.description: Unit tests allow you to test the contract methods individually. They are suitable to check the storage is updated correctly, and that methods return their expected values. They are written in the contract's language and execute locally.

build/smart-contracts/what-is.title: What is a Smart Contract?
build/smart-contracts/what-is.description: Smart contracts are pieces of executable code that live in a NEAR account. They can store data, perform transactions in the account‚Äôs name, and expose methods so other accounts can interact with them.

build/web3-apps/backend/backend-login.title: Authenticate NEAR Users
build/web3-apps/backend/backend-login.description: Recently NEAR has approved a new standard that, among other things, enables users to authenticate into a backend service.

build/web3-apps/frontend.title: Frontends for Web3 dApps
build/web3-apps/frontend.description: When building decentralized web applications (dApps), developers have two primary options for connecting a front-end user interface (UI) to a smart contract backend. Each option offers distinct advantages and disadvantages, tailored to different project requirements and goals.

build/web3-apps/integrate-components.title: Integrating Components
build/web3-apps/integrate-components.description: To integrate Components to your frontend, you will leverage two tools:

build/web3-apps/integrate-contracts.title: Integrating Contracts
build/web3-apps/integrate-contracts.description: To integrate NEAR to your frontend, you will leverage two tools:

build/web3-apps/quickstart.title: Hello WebApp
build/web3-apps/quickstart.description: Most interactions with the NEAR ecosystem can be grouped in 2 categories:

build/web3-apps/what-is.title: What are Web3 Apps?
build/web3-apps/what-is.description: Web3 Applications - also known as decentralized apps (dApps) - leverage smart contracts and blockchain data to offer transparency, security and giving back control to users over their assets and data.

concepts/abstraction/chain-signatures.title: What are Chain Signatures?
concepts/abstraction/chain-signatures.description: Chain signatures enable NEAR accounts, including smart contracts, to sign and execute transactions across many blockchain protocols.

concepts/abstraction/introduction.title: Chain Abstraction
concepts/abstraction/introduction.description: Do you know how your favorite apps are built and which database they use? Chances are not, since we choose apps based on their functionality, and not their underlying tech.

concepts/abstraction/meta-transactions.title: Meta Transactions
concepts/abstraction/meta-transactions.description: NEP-366 introduced the concept of meta

concepts/abstraction/relayers.title: Relayers
concepts/abstraction/relayers.description: A relayer is a simple web service that receives signed transactions from NEAR users, and relays them to the network while attaching tokens to sponsor their GAS expenses. This can be useful to create applications in which the users are not required to purchase NEAR in order to be able to transact. In this document we present a high-level overview on how relayers work. Please check the build a relayer page if you want to learn how to build your own relayer.

concepts/abstraction/signatures/use-case.title: Use cases for Chain Signatures
concepts/abstraction/signatures/use-case.description: Chain signatures enable you to implement multichain and cross-chain workflows in a simple way.

concepts/advanced/indexers.title: Introduction to Indexers
concepts/advanced/indexers.description: Here you will find everything you need to know in order to familiarize yourself with the concept of indexers and even build your own one.

concepts/basics/epoch.title: Epoch
concepts/basics/epoch.description: An epoch is a unit of time when validators of the network remain constant. It is measured in blocks:

concepts/basics/networks.title: NEAR Networks
concepts/basics/networks.description: NEAR Protocol operates on several networks each operating with their own independent validators and unique state. These networks are as follows:

concepts/basics/protocol.title: What is NEAR?
concepts/basics/protocol.description: NEAR is a user-friendly and carbon-neutral blockchain, built to be fast, secure, and able to grow without limits.

concepts/basics/runtime.title: Runtime
concepts/basics/runtime.description: This section contains videos that explore the core Runtime, its operation, and how it implements cross-contract calls.

concepts/basics/token-loss.title: Avoiding Token Loss
concepts/basics/token-loss.description: Careful! Losing tokens means losing money!

concepts/basics/tokens.title: Tokens
concepts/basics/tokens.description: This is the native token used in NEAR Protocol.

concepts/basics/validators.title: Validators
concepts/basics/validators.description: The NEAR network is decentralized, meaning that multiple people collaborate in order to keep it safe. We call such people validators.

concepts/data-flow/data-storage.title: Data on the Blockchain
concepts/data-flow/data-storage.description: This article will cover a high-level overview of Blockchain concepts and tools which facilitate reading and writing Blockchain data.

concepts/data-flow/token-transfer-flow.title: Token Transfer flow
concepts/data-flow/token-transfer-flow.description: In the previous article we saw an example of token transfer between accounts found in different shards. That example was simplified and missed a few steps in the process. That was intentional, to keep the article and the video short yet explanatory, in order to give you a bigger picture for understanding concepts.

concepts/protocol/access-keys.title: Access Keys
concepts/protocol/access-keys.description: In all blockchains, users control their accounts by holding a private key (a secret only they know) and using it to sign transactions.

concepts/protocol/account-id.title: Address (Account ID)
concepts/protocol/account-id.description: NEAR accounts are identified by a unique address, which take one of two forms:

concepts/protocol/account-model.title: NEAR Accounts
concepts/protocol/account-model.description: Users participate in the NEAR ecosystem through their NEAR accounts. These accounts are identified by a unique address, can optionally hold a smart contract, and are controlled through Access Keys.

concepts/protocol/gas.title: Gas (Execution Fees)
concepts/protocol/gas.description: On every transaction the NEAR network charges a tiny fee known as gas. This fee is a simple mechanism that allows us to:

concepts/protocol/smartcontract.title: Smart Contract
concepts/protocol/smartcontract.description: Smart contracts are pieces of executable code that live in a NEAR account. They can store data, perform transactions in the account‚Äôs name, and expose methods so other accounts can interact with them.

concepts/protocol/transaction-anatomy.title: Anatomy of a Transaction
concepts/protocol/transaction-anatomy.description: A transaction is a request from a user to the network to perform a set of actions. To create a transaction, the user must specify the following fields:

concepts/protocol/transaction-execution.title: Lifecycle of a Transaction
concepts/protocol/transaction-execution.description: Transactions are constructed by users to express the intent of performing actions in the network. Once in the network, transactions are converted into Receipts, which are messages exchanged between network nodes.

concepts/protocol/transactions.title: Transactions
concepts/protocol/transactions.description: Users interact with NEAR by creating transactions. Specifically, user's use their account's private keys to sign transactions, which are then broadcasted and processed by the network.

concepts/storage/storage-solutions.title: Decentralized Storage Solutions
concepts/storage/storage-solutions.description: In this article you'll find a brief overview of different decentralized storage solutions that can be integrated into your decentralized applications (dApps). This will allow you to store large amounts of data using a more economical alternative to native NEAR storage.

concepts/storage/storage-staking.title: Storage Staking
concepts/storage/storage-staking.description: When you deploy a smart contract to NEAR, you pay for the storage that this contract requires using a mechanism called storage staking.

concepts/web3/basics.title: Blockchain basics
concepts/web3/basics.description: Before diving deeper into the intricacies of Web 3 development, let‚Äôs explore what it is and why it exists.

concepts/web3/economics.title: Web 3.0 Economics
concepts/web3/economics.description: With technological decentralization also came economical decentralization. It stands on 3 pillars - Non-Fungible tokens (NFTs), Fungible tokens (FTs) and Decentralized Finance (DeFi).

concepts/web3/near.title: NEAR Protocol
concepts/web3/near.description: For the beginners, it‚Äôs always better to start with documentation, and NEAR has an excellent one. Here, we only focus on basic concepts which are necessary to understand later chapters, so an entire guideline could be understood without prior NEAR knowledge.

concepts/web3/nfts.title: NFTs for Web 2 Applications
concepts/web3/nfts.description: At the first stage of our Web 3 transformation, let‚Äôs decentralize ownership of our digital assets using blockchain technology. By doing this, we can create a user-owned economy, where digital assets are exchanged and traded without any participation or control from the developers. Later, we‚Äôll discuss how to bring it to the next level by adding Fungible Tokens into the mix.

concepts/welcome.title: NEAR Protocol Overview
concepts/welcome.description: Welcome! Here we will explain you what NEAR Protocol is, its components, and how it works.

help.title: NEAR - Your Gateway to an Open Web

integrations/create-transactions.title: Create Transactions
integrations/create-transactions.description: To construct & process transactions you will need our API JavaScript library: near-api-js. There are many ways to create transactions but for this example we'll show you two ways to create a simple token transfer transaction.

integrations/errors/error-implementation.title: Source Code Survey
integrations/errors/error-implementation.description: This page provides a very high level, sometimes "pseudocode", view of error types and related messages as implemented by the NEAR platform.

integrations/errors/token-loss.title: Avoiding Token Loss
integrations/errors/token-loss.description: Careful! Losing tokens means losing money!

pagoda/alerts/intro.title: Pagoda Alerts & Triggers
pagoda/alerts/intro.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

pagoda/alerts/setup.title: Setup Alerts & Triggers
pagoda/alerts/setup.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

pagoda/alerts/webhooks.title: Turn on the (Hue) lights with NEAR NFTs and Pagoda Alerts & Triggers
pagoda/alerts/webhooks.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

pagoda/rpc/api.title: NEAR Enhanced API
pagoda/rpc/api.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

pagoda/rpc/get-keys.title: Get Pagoda API Keys
pagoda/rpc/get-keys.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

pagoda/rpc/intro.title: Pagoda RPC API
pagoda/rpc/intro.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

pagoda/rpc/setup.title: RPC Setup
pagoda/rpc/setup.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

pagoda/rpc/stats.title: RPC Statistics
pagoda/rpc/stats.description: Please be advised that these tools and services will be discontinued soon.

tools/explorer.title: Explorer
tools/explorer.description: An Explorer allows you to quickly obtain information from the blockchain through a friendly user interface.

tools/fastnear-api.title: FastNEAR API
tools/fastnear-api.description: A fast RPC for the NEAR blockchain, based on Redis and LMDB.

tools/indexing.title: Indexing Solutions on NEAR
tools/indexing.description: Here's a quick overview of Indexer projects on the NEAR ecosystem:

tools/near-api-js/account.title: Account
tools/near-api-js/account.description: You can interact with, create or delete NEAR accounts.

tools/near-api-js/contract.title: Contract
tools/near-api-js/contract.description: When you instantiate an instance of Contract you need to specify the names of the functions you have on your smart contract.

tools/near-api-js/cookbook.title: Common Use Cases
tools/near-api-js/cookbook.description: The repository contains many recipes that you can readily use to solve common case scenarios.

tools/near-api-js/faq.title: FAQ for NEAR JavaScript API
tools/near-api-js/faq.description: A collection of Frequently Asked Questions by the community.

tools/near-api-js/quick-reference.title: Using JavaScript API to interact with NEAR

tools/near-api-js/wallet.title: Interacting with the Wallet
tools/near-api-js/wallet.description: Wallet interaction is possible only in the browser, because NEAR's Wallet is web-based.

tools/near-cli.title: NEAR CLI
tools/near-cli.description: The NEAR Command Line Interface (CLI) is a tool that enables to interact with the NEAR network directly from the shell. Among other things, the NEAR CLI enables you to:

tools/sdk.title: NEAR SDK
tools/sdk.description: The NEAR SDK is a library that allow to develop smart contracts. Currently, there exist two versions of NEAR SDK: one for Rust and one for JavaScript.

tools/wallet-selector.title: Wallet Selector
tools/wallet-selector.description: An easy-to-navigate modal that allows users to select their preferred wallet to easily interact with the NEAR protocol.

tools/wallets.title: Wallets
tools/wallets.description: Here's a range of user-friendly wallets that support the NEAR blockchain:

tools/welcome.title: Tools
tools/welcome.description: Welcome! The NEAR ecosystem has a complete set of tools for you to make the most out of the NEAR network.

tutorials/crosswords/basics/add-function.title: Alter the smart contract, learning about basics of development
tutorials/crosswords/basics/add-function.description: This section will modify the smart contract skeleton from the previous section. This tutorial will start by writing a contract in a somewhat useless way in order to learn the basics. Once we've got a solid understanding, we'll iterate until we have a crossword puzzle.

tutorials/crosswords/basics/hashing-and-.title: Introduction to basic hashing and adding unit tests
tutorials/crosswords/basics/hashing-and-.description: In the previous section, we stored the crossword solution as plain text as a String type on the smart contract. If we're trying to hide the solution from the users, this isn't a great approach as it'll be public to anyone looking at the state. Let's instead hash our crossword solution and store that instead. There are different ways to hash data, but let's use sha256 which is one of the hashing algorithms available in the Rust SDK.

tutorials/crosswords/basics/overview.title: Basics overview laying out what will be accomplished in this first section.
tutorials/crosswords/basics/overview.description: This first chapter of the crossword puzzle tutorial will introduce fundamental concepts to smart contract development in a beginner-friendly way. By the end of this chapter you'll have a proof-of-concept contract that can be interacted with via NEAR CLI and a simple frontend that uses the near-api-js library.

tutorials/crosswords/basics/set-up-skele.title: Set up Rust, get a NEAR testnet account, NEAR CLI, and get a basic smart contract skeleton ready
tutorials/crosswords/basics/set-up-skele.description: In this tutorial we'll get a testnet account, use NEAR CLI RS to add a key to our computer's file system, and set up the basic skeleton of a Rust smart contract.

tutorials/crosswords/basics/simple-front.title: Add a simple frontend to the crossword puzzle that checks the solution's hash
tutorials/crosswords/basics/simple-front.description: This will be the final section in this chapter, where we'll add a simple frontend using React and near-api-js to communicate with the smart contract.

tutorials/crosswords/beginner/actions.title: There are several Actions an account can do, including sending the winner of the crossword puzzle NEAR using the Transfer Action
tutorials/crosswords/beginner/actions.description: We're going to introduce a new Action: Transfer. In this chapter, we'd like the first person to solve the crossword puzzle to earn some prize money, sent in NEAR.

tutorials/crosswords/beginner/adding-a-p.title: Adding a new puzzle now that we're using a collection that can contain multiple crossword puzzles
tutorials/crosswords/beginner/adding-a-p.description: We're going to make a new puzzle, which means we need to provide the smart contract with a set of clues and info about the answers.

tutorials/crosswords/beginner/collection.title: Store multiple crossword puzzles using a specialized collection in NEAR called a LookupMap
tutorials/crosswords/beginner/collection.description: As mentioned in the previous chapter, the online Rust Book is a great reference for folks getting started with Rust, but there are concepts that differ when we're dealing with the blockchain. One of these differences is the use of collections.

tutorials/crosswords/beginner/overview.title: Highlights of some beginner topics covered.
tutorials/crosswords/beginner/overview.description: In the last chapter we installed Rust and got up and running with a simple smart contract. The contract has a few issues, however, and isn't as powerful as we'd like it to be. For instance, we can only store one crossword puzzle in the smart contract, the frontend is  hardcoded, and we don't offer any incentives to the person who wins.

tutorials/crosswords/beginner/structs-en.title: How to think about structs and enums when writing a Rust smart contract on NEAR

tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/access.title: Replacing the solution hash with an access key
tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/access.description: So far in this tutorial, the user sends the plaintext solution to the crossword puzzle smart contract, where it's hashed and compared with the known answer.

tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/base64.title: Using base64-encoded arguments when we create a new crossword puzzle
tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/base64.description: Let's modify our new_puzzle method a bit, and demonstrate how a smart contract author might use base64-encoded arguments.

tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/cross-.title: Adding cross-contract calls, access key shuffling, etc.
tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/cross-.description: To reiterate, we'd like anyone to be able to participate in the crossword puzzle, even folks who don't have a NEAR account.

tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/linkdr.title: Introducing the linkdrop contract we can use
tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/linkdr.description: We're going to take a small detour to talk about the linkdrop smart contract.  It's best that we first understand this contract and its purpose, then discuss calling a method on this contract.

tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/overvi.title: Intermediate concepts (cross-contract calls and more)
tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/overvi.description: This chapter will go a bit faster than the previous ones.

tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/use-se.title: Implementing the seed phrase logic from the necessary libraries
tutorials/crosswords/intermediate/use-se.description: There are two separate things we'll want to do:

tutorials/examples/advanced-xcc.title: Complex Cross Contract Call
tutorials/examples/advanced-xcc.description: This example presents 3 instances of complex cross-contract calls. Particularly, it shows:

tutorials/examples/coin-flip.title: Coin Flip
tutorials/examples/coin-flip.description: Coin Flip is a game where the player tries to guess the outcome of a coin flip. It is one of the simplest contracts implementing random numbers.

tutorials/examples/count-near.title: Count on NEAR
tutorials/examples/count-near.description: Our counter example is a friendly decentralized app that stores a number and exposes methods to increment,

tutorials/examples/donation.title: Donation
tutorials/examples/donation.description: Our donation example enables to forward NEAR Tokens to an account while keeping track of it. It is one of the simplest examples on making a contract handle tranfers.

tutorials/examples/factory.title: Factory
tutorials/examples/factory.description: A factory is a smart contract that stores a compiled contract on itself, and automatizes deploying it into

tutorials/examples/frontend-multiple-con.title: Frontend Interacting with Multiple Contracts
tutorials/examples/frontend-multiple-con.description: This example showcases how to interact with multiple contracts from a single frontend.

tutorials/examples/guest-book.title: Guest Book
tutorials/examples/guest-book.description: Our Guest Book example is a simple app composed by two main components:

tutorials/examples/update-contract-migra.title: Self Upgrade & State Migration
tutorials/examples/update-contract-migra.description: Three examples on how to handle updates and state migration:

tutorials/examples/xcc.title: Cross Contract Call
tutorials/examples/xcc.description: This example performs the simplest cross-contract call possible: it calls our Hello NEAR example to set and retrieve a greeting.

tutorials/fts/circulating-supply.title: Creating a Circulating Supply
tutorials/fts/circulating-supply.description: In the previous tutorial, you looked at what a fungible token was and how you could define one in your smart contract. In this tutorial, you'll learn how to create a circulating supply belonging to the contract owner and view all the tokens, with their metadata, in the NEAR wallet.

tutorials/fts/defining-a-token.title: Defining a Fungible Token
tutorials/fts/defining-a-token.description: This is the first of many tutorials in a series where you'll be creating a complete FT smart contract from scratch that conforms with all the NEAR FT standards. Today you'll learn what a Fungible Token is and how you can define one on the NEAR blockchain. You will be modifying a bare-bones skeleton smart contract by filling in the necessary code snippets needed to add this functionality.

tutorials/fts/introduction.title: Fungible Tokens Zero to Hero
tutorials/fts/introduction.description: In this Zero to Hero series, you'll find a set of tutorials covering every aspect of a fungible token (FT) smart contract. You'll start by interacting with a pre-deployed contract and by the end you'll have built a fully-fledged FT smart contract that supports every extension of the standards.

tutorials/fts/marketplace.title: Integrating FT Payments into an NFT Marketplace
tutorials/fts/marketplace.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn the basics of how an NFT marketplace contract works and how you can modify it to allow for purchasing NFTs using Fungible Tokens. In the previous tutorials, you went through and created a fully fledged FT contract that incorporates all the standards found in the FT standard.

tutorials/fts/predeployed-contract.title: Pre-deployed Contract
tutorials/fts/predeployed-contract.description: Learn how to easily receive fungible tokens without doing any software development by using a readily-available FT smart contract.

tutorials/fts/registering-accounts.title: Registering Accounts
tutorials/fts/registering-accounts.description: In the previous tutorial, you looked at how to mint an initial circulating supply of tokens and how you could log events as per the events standard. You then deployed the contract and saw the FTs in your wallet balance. In this tutorial, you'll learn about the storage management standard and how you can register accounts in your FT contract in order to prevent a malicious party from draining your contract of all its funds.

tutorials/fts/skeleton.title: Skeleton and Rust Architecture
tutorials/fts/skeleton.description: In this article, you'll learn about the basic architecture behind the FT contract that you'll develop while following this "Zero to Hero" series. You'll discover the contract's layout and you'll see how the Rust files are structured in order to build a feature-complete smart contract.

tutorials/fts/transfers.title: Transferring Fungible Tokens
tutorials/fts/transfers.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to implement the core standards into your smart contract. You'll implement the logic that allows you to transfer and receive tokens. If you're joining us for the first time, feel free to clone this repository and follow along in the 4.storage folder.

tutorials/near-components/blog-posts.title: Blog Posts
tutorials/near-components/blog-posts.description: The Blog post components enable your gateway to promote regular Near Social posts into fully fledged blog posts.

tutorials/near-components/bos-loader.title: BOS Loader
tutorials/near-components/bos-loader.description: In this article you'll learn how to develop, test, and deploy BOS components using CLI tools. You can use this workflow to tap into the colaboration, pull-request, and other GitHub benefits while still deploying components to the BOS.

tutorials/near-components/ds-components.title: Design Components
tutorials/near-components/ds-components.description: When building components, the NEAR VM provides a complete set of Radix primitives to simplify UI development.

tutorials/near-components/ethers-js.title: NEAR for Ethereum developers
tutorials/near-components/ethers-js.description: NEAR components are chain-agnostic, enabling you to create decentralized frontends tailored for any Ethereum dApps. Throughout this article, we'll navigate prevalent use-cases with code snippets. You‚Äôll also find links to exemplary NEAR components for reference.

tutorials/near-components/ethers-js-best.title: Best Practices for Ethereum developers on NEAR
tutorials/near-components/ethers-js-best.description: In this example, we will create an Ethereum dApp on NEAR that functions as a portfolio manager, displaying the current balances for a list of tokens. Additionally, we will display current market value of each asset in the portfolio.

tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.title: Social Feed Indexer
tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.description: This tutorial creates a blockchain indexer using NEAR QueryAPI.

tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.title: Hype Indexer
tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.description: This tutorial creates a blockchain indexer using NEAR QueryAPI.

tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.title: Minted NFTs Indexer
tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.description: This tutorial creates a blockchain indexer using NEAR QueryAPI.

tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.title: Posts Indexer
tutorials/near-components/indexer-tutori.description: This tutorial creates a blockchain indexer using NEAR QueryAPI.

tutorials/near-components/interaction.title: Smart Contract Interaction
tutorials/near-components/interaction.description: Your frontend can interact with different blockchains using the built-in BOS API. Let's see how to create an application that reads and stores a greeting from a NEAR smart contract.

tutorials/near-components/lido.title: Lido Example
tutorials/near-components/lido.description: If you are ready to explore further, the Lido component serves as an excellent fully-fledged example, as it demonstrates how to interact with a smart contract deployed on the Ethereum mainnet.

tutorials/near-components/push-notificat.title: Push Notifications
tutorials/near-components/push-notificat.description: Push messages enable your gateway to send notifications on desktop and mobile devices even when the users are not active.

tutorials/near-components/queryapi-webso.title: WebSocket-enabled Components with QueryAPI
tutorials/near-components/queryapi-webso.description: In this article you'll learn how to create a NEAR component that gathers information from a QueryAPI indexer using WebSockets.

tutorials/near-components/using-iframes.title: Using IFrames
tutorials/near-components/using-iframes.description: In this tutorial you'll learn how to use the iframe VM tag and the Iframe resizer library, so you can embed external HTML or use custom DOM elements when building NEAR components.

tutorials/nfts/approvals.title: Approvals
tutorials/nfts/approvals.description: In this tutorial you'll learn the basics of an approval management system which will allow you to grant others access to transfer NFTs on your behalf.

tutorials/nfts/core.title: Transfers
tutorials/nfts/core.description: In this tutorial you'll learn how to implement NFT transfers as defined in the core standards into your smart contract.

tutorials/nfts/enumeration.title: Enumeration
tutorials/nfts/enumeration.description: In the previous tutorials, you looked at ways to integrate the minting functionality into a skeleton smart contract. In order to get your NFTs to show in the wallet, you also had to deploy a patch fix that implemented one of the enumeration methods. In this tutorial, you'll expand on and finish the rest of the enumeration methods as per the standard.

tutorials/nfts/events.title: Events
tutorials/nfts/events.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn about the events standard and how to implement it in your smart contract.

tutorials/nfts/introduction.title: NFT Zero to Hero
tutorials/nfts/introduction.description: In this Zero to Hero series, you'll find a set of tutorials that will cover every aspect of a non-fungible token (NFT) smart contract.

tutorials/nfts/js/approvals.title: Approvals
tutorials/nfts/js/approvals.description: In this tutorial you'll learn the basics of an approval management system which will allow you to grant others access to transfer NFTs on your behalf. This is the backbone of all NFT marketplaces and allows for some complex yet beautiful scenarios to happen. If you're joining us for the first time, feel free to clone this repository and checkout the 4.core branch to follow along.

tutorials/nfts/js/core.title: Core
tutorials/nfts/js/core.description: In this tutorial you'll learn how to implement the core standards into your smart contract. If you're joining us for the first time, feel free to clone this repo and checkout the 3.enumeration branch to follow along.

tutorials/nfts/js/enumeration.title: Enumeration
tutorials/nfts/js/enumeration.description: In the previous tutorials, you looked at ways to integrate the minting functionality into a skeleton smart contract. In order to get your NFTs to show in the wallet, you also had to deploy a patch fix that implemented one of the enumeration methods. In this tutorial, you'll expand on and finish the rest of the enumeration methods as per the standard

tutorials/nfts/js/events.title: Events
tutorials/nfts/js/events.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn about the events standard and how to implement it in your smart contract.

tutorials/nfts/js/introduction.title: NFT Zero to Hero JavaScript Edition
tutorials/nfts/js/introduction.description: In this Zero to Hero series, you'll find a set of tutorials that will cover every aspect of a non-fungible token (NFT) smart contract.

tutorials/nfts/js/marketplace.title: Marketplace
tutorials/nfts/js/marketplace.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn the basics of an NFT marketplace contract where you can buy and sell non-fungible tokens for $NEAR. In the previous tutorials, you went through and created a fully fledged NFT contract that incorporates all the standards found in the NFT standard.

tutorials/nfts/js/minting.title: Minting
tutorials/nfts/js/minting.description: This is the first of many tutorials in a series where you'll be creating a complete NFT smart contract from scratch that conforms with all the NEAR NFT standards. Today you'll learn how to create the logic needed to mint NFTs and have them show up in your NEAR wallet. You will be modifying a bare-bones skeleton smart contract by filling in the necessary code snippets needed to add minting functionalities.

tutorials/nfts/js/predeployed-contract.title: Pre-deployed Contract
tutorials/nfts/js/predeployed-contract.description: Learn how to easily create your own non-fungible tokens without doing any software development by using a readily-available NFT smart contract.

tutorials/nfts/js/royalty.title: Royalty
tutorials/nfts/js/royalty.description: In this tutorial you'll continue building your non-fungible token (NFT) smart contract, and learn how to implement perpetual royalties into your NFTs. This will allow people to get a percentage of the purchase price when an NFT is sold.

tutorials/nfts/js/skeleton.title: Skeleton and JavaScript Architecture
tutorials/nfts/js/skeleton.description: In this article, you'll learn about the basic architecture behind the NFT contract that you'll develop while following this "Zero to Hero" series.

tutorials/nfts/js/upgrade-contract.title: Upgrading the Contract
tutorials/nfts/js/upgrade-contract.description: In this tutorial, you'll build off the work you previously did to implement the minting functionality on a skeleton smart contract. You got to the point where NFTs could be minted, however, the wallet had no way of displaying the tokens since your contract didn't implement the method that the wallet was trying to call.

tutorials/nfts/marketplace.title: Marketplace
tutorials/nfts/marketplace.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn the basics of an NFT marketplace contract where you can buy and sell non-fungible tokens for $NEAR. In the previous tutorials, you went through and created a fully fledged NFT contract that incorporates all the standards found in the NFT standard.

tutorials/nfts/minecraft-nfts.title: Create NFTs in Minecraft
tutorials/nfts/minecraft-nfts.description: In this tutorial you'll learn how to take your custom Minecraft creations and mint the schematics into NFTs on the NEAR blockchain!

tutorials/nfts/minting.title: Minting
tutorials/nfts/minting.description: This is the first of many tutorials in a series where you'll be creating a complete NFT smart contract from scratch that conforms with all the NEAR NFT standards.

tutorials/nfts/minting-nft-frontend.title: Minting NFT Front-end
tutorials/nfts/minting-nft-frontend.description: In this tutorial you'll learn how to create a simple NFT front-end and mint a "Go Team" NFT on the NEAR blockchain straight from your web browser.

tutorials/nfts/minting-nfts.title: Minting NFTs
tutorials/nfts/minting-nfts.description: In this tutorial you'll learn how to easily create your own NFTs without doing any software development by using a readily-available smart contract and a decentralized storage solution like IPFS.

tutorials/nfts/predeployed-contract.title: Pre-deployed Contract
tutorials/nfts/predeployed-contract.description: Create your first non-fungible token by using a pre-deployed NFT smart contract which works exactly as the one you will build on this tutorial.

tutorials/nfts/royalty.title: Royalty
tutorials/nfts/royalty.description: In this tutorial you'll continue building your non-fungible token (NFT) smart contract, and learn how to implement perpetual royalties into your NFTs. This will allow people to get a percentage of the purchase price when an NFT is sold.

tutorials/nfts/series.title: Customizing the NFT Contract
tutorials/nfts/series.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to take the existing NFT contract you've been working with and modify it to meet some of the most common needs in the ecosystem. This includes:

tutorials/nfts/skeleton.title: Skeleton and Rust Architecture
tutorials/nfts/skeleton.description: In this article, you'll learn about the basic architecture behind the NFT contract that you'll develop while following this "Zero to Hero" series.

tutorials/nfts/upgrade-contract.title: Upgrading the Contract
tutorials/nfts/upgrade-contract.description: In this tutorial, you'll build off the work you previously did to implement the minting functionality on a skeleton smart contract. You got to the point where NFTs could be minted and the wallet correctly picked up on the fact that you owned an NFT. However, it had no way of displaying the tokens since your contract didn't implement the method that the wallet was trying to call.

tutorials/welcome.title: Examples & Tutorials
tutorials/welcome.description: Explore our collection of Examples and Tutorials

welcome.title: Welcome to NEAR
welcome.description: Imagine a place were you can build Web3 apps with the simplicity of Web2. Imagine a place were you can empower communities, supercharge AI and easily integrate your app with other chains. Welcome to NEAR, you're gonna like it here.
